title: The marriage premium revisited: the case of baseball
abstractText:
Using a sample of professional baseball players, Cornaglia and Feldman plan to analyse a longstanding empirical observation that married men earn significantly more than their never-married counterparts, holding all else equal. 

This differential in wages is interpreted as reflecting a difference in productivity.  Thus, the more direct question is whether marriage causes an increase in productivity for men.  There are numerous conflicting explanations, some of which are causal (that is, marriage does indeed increase productivity for men) and some of which reflect more subtle sample selection problems (that is, men who tend to be successful in the workplace also tend to be successful in attracting a spouse). 

Using regression analysis, the authors plan to collect data on marital status and other relevant variables on professional baseball players.  Baseball is a unique case study because it has a long history of statistics collection and numerous direct measurements of productivity.  In addition, because of the long collection period of baseball statistics, they can analyse the effect of marriage on productivity for well over a century (1871-2007) and also re-evaluate gender discrimination in the marketplace once true productivity differences are taken into account.
